This GLC looks really like compact SUV.

The first images of Mercedes-Benz's new GLC that replaces the squared GLK compact SUV have trickled on the web.
 

 
A rival to Audi's Q5, BMW's X3 and Volvo's XC60, the GLC was introduced today during a special event in Stuttgart, Germany, and will go on sale in Europe later this year, with North America to get the SUV in mid-November, at as of yet, undisclosed prices. And unlike the outgoing GLK, the new GLC will be made available to right-hand drive markets, including, of course, Britain. 
 



 
Linked to Mercedes' C-Class series – hence the change in the name from GLK to GLC, the SUV rides on a longer wheelbase version of the sedan's Modular Rear Architecture and will be offered in Europe with a starting lineup of three engines. These include the diesel-powered GLC 220d 4Matic with 168hp (0-62mph or 100km/h in 8.3 sec and 56mpg UK), and GLC 250d 4Matic with 201hp (0-62mph or 100km/h in 7.6 sec and 56mpg UK), and the petrol GLC 250 4Matic with 208hp (0-62mph or 100km/h in 7.3 sec and 43mpg UK).In North America, the GLC will launch this fall as the rear-wheel drive GLC 300 and all-wheel drive GLC 300 4Matic, which should have the same 241hp 2.0-liter turbocharged four as the C300 sedan – we're still waiting for Mercedes' to release US specs. 
 


 
Additional powertrains, including a plug-in hybrid variant and AMG models, will follow later on.
 





 
Source: Carscoops

Bye bye BMW...

Not so long ago, X6 which broke convention was heavily criticised for being a car that addressed a problem nobody raised. Nobody needed the car, its a 4 seater, its impractical, and its ugly. 
 
Then, LR followed suite with its Evoque. Now Merc go all in with not 1 but 2 SUV coupes. ... GLE coupe and GLC coupe .... and possibly a GLS coupe in the coming years. 
 
To me, they all look the same. A coupe on stilt with large wheel arches and wide tyres. 
 
The GLC (both coupe and SUV) interior is directly taken from W205 C class ... while it pleases the mainstream, i still dont like the steering mounted gear stalk and the gimmicky touch interface "mouse" on control knob. While the switch gears of the new Mercs of high perceived quality, its ergonomics is both well thought and has learning curve. 
 
X4 comparatively uses the older X3 interior instead of the F32/34 newer design. Probably their mistake, but its ergonomics is direct, no nonsense, and iDrive natural to use. Its doesnt look as sophisticated as the GLC, but functional nonetheless. 
 
Exterior looks is highly subjective. Its like comparing Matt Damon to Will Smith. Neither look particularly handsome.... but attractive in their own way. 
 
If i have to choose one, since neither appeals to me physically, its the chassis and drive train (the inner beauty) that matters. In this case, the bimmer drives like an ultimate driving machine, whereas the GLC is but an eye candy. To some, that is all that matters... a trophy to behold and to show off.

Having sat in all of the new mercs recently, C class, regular GLC, GLC Coupe and E class I think this is the new way merc makes their rear seat. Shorter "thigh" length, thus creating a visually more spacious feel. but if one is used to a full size rear bench config, etc F10 or S60, sure will feel short changed.
 
But then again I think its still reasonable for Asian males 1.7m-1.8m bcos we don't sit super upright anyways and will naturally slouch..that being said, I do feel the E class and regular GLC feels almost identical in terms of sitting space and sitting angle. The GLC Coupe, same leg room but feels a tad more upright, just a tiny bit 5 degree maybe, but still pretty comfy tbh.

The GLC itself is a mishmash of Mercedes componentry, specifically the chassis and mechanical bits of the E-Class and the interior and electronics from the C-Class. We find this to be a particularly brilliant way to build a crossover. “One of the deciding factors for me was the decision to use the E-Class platform and C-Class features,” Alisa Priddle said in explaining her vote. “That’s the smart way to engineer a product.”
Added guest judge Mike Accavitti: “Overall, this is a great vehicle. You know you’re getting into a Mercedes as soon as you open the door to the GLC. The quality of the materials and the elegance of the design are very consistent with the Mercedes-Benz brand proposition and reputation.”
The platform itself is Mercedes’ clever Modular Rear Architecture platform, which will eventually underpin 10 models, including the C- and E-Class and an upcoming replacement for the defunct R-Class. The GLC’s 113.1-inch wheelbase nearly splits the difference between the 111.8-inch C-Class and the 115.7-inch E-Class. The length translates primarily into rear-seat space, including extra headroom when compared to a direct competitor such as the Cadillac XT5.
A bunch of Germans I know joke that the GLC is the cheapest E-Class you can buy. They ain’t joking.

As the GLC doesn’t have the fancier interior of the E-Class, a bunch of Germans I know like to joke that it is the cheapest E-Class you can buy. Thing is, they ain’t joking. The C-Class interior is the best in its class, and most folks couldn’t tell it apart from an E-Class anyway. “This thing is just nice,” Christian Seabaugh said. “I hop in and immediately feel relaxed. The seats are sofa soft yet still supportive. All the touch points feel like a million bucks.” Accavitti: “It’s very luxurious looking with lots of leather and wood. I love how the infotainment system warns you not to be distracted by it, but then it has all these awesome screens you can’t help be distracted by.” Angus MacKenzie summed up the interior well: “Looks rich and upscale, like a mini S-Class. It sets the benchmark for a small luxury SUV.”

 The C&C GLC selling price list is just a guideline base on the current COE.  When you place your deposit,  it is stated clearly the only thibg confirmed is the selling price of the car without COE which is slightly less than 190k.When your car goes into factory production (about 3-4mth before expected delivery) ,  then they will package your car with coe. Usually not car price + coe premium.  There will be a 10-20 k off the premium.  It is not a discount but more like they already factored that 10-20k into ur car price. 
Since GLC is not ex-stock,  do not expect big carrots or discounts.

for the benefit of forumers having GLC and NX Luxury/F-sport (AD specced model) in the their shopping cart deciding which one to check out on, I share some of the research and information I accumulated while doing my own shopping a couple of months back. Pardon me if the details are a little rusty.
 
I shall skip the nity gritty details on aesthetics since it is pretty personal (eg. @Radx said the NX front grill looks like his favourite part of the female anatomy...i digressed  )
 
Engine:
Pretty similar 2.0T engine for both with similar torque at 350nm. HP figure GLC lower by 20 but acceleration timing is pretty matched up. I think it has something to do with the AWD and 9-Gtronics which I shall elaborate later.
 
Transmission:
NX is the trusty 6 speeder while the GLC has the all new 9-Gtronics. I can only compare the 9-Gtronics with the prev 7Gtronics, it is much smoother. More ratios to play with and an efficient smooth gear engagement process contributed to the acceleration figure despite having a lower HP figure.
 
Drivetrain:
NX AWD is a full time FWD and part time AWD which engage only when slip is detected. 
GLC 4matic is a full time AWD with a permanent 45:55 front/rear split with a more rear wheel driven sporty bias
The 4matic probably contributed to the straight line acceleration figure by transferring the power to the ground better.
 
Lighting:
GLC comes with Intelligent LED System which means is full LED and is active (cornering illumination etc)
NX come with Tri-LED system which I assume is active as well.
 
Parking:
GLC only rear view camera but has automatic parking
NX has all round 360 view and IIRC automatic parking
 
Interior comforts:
GLC artico synthetic leather
NX real leather
 
GLC seat ventilation is an option
NX standard
 
GLC panoramic roof is a 7K option
NX panoramic roof is standard for luxury and not available for F-sport
 
GLC rear seat has only 2 adjustable angle
NX rear sear has electronic variable angle adjustment for the luxury version. not available for F-sport (IIRC)
 
GLC factory stock Audio 20 entertainment system with 8 speakers
NX lexus 10 speakers system (not the Mark Levinsons IIRC)
 
Safety:
GLC Collision Prevention Assist Plus + Adaptive braking.... essentially it uses sensors to detect front traffic and give visual and audio warning to warn if you are travelling too close and there will be partial autonomous braking if the system feels that you are not braking hard enough. Not full automatic braking but it helps reduce the chance of impact and extend of damage
NX no such system.
 
 
Warranty:
GLC 3 years
NX 5 years
 
 
hope this helps!

Waited 3 months till date...if my butt feel is right, there should be another 3-4mths to go given that MB started a second factory line dedicated to GLC production outside of Bremen, Germany starting 2017. That is why the waiting time has shorten gradually from the 1 yr initially.
 
Only consolation for the wait is that I get to option in the pano roof and amg line (the standard CnC exterior trim is the outdoor package trim with too much chrome front and back). Current buyers have to pick and choose from the models CnC pre-configured and on order from the factory, that explains the even shorter wait time.
 
Lexus NX the actual sale price has always been about 15-20K lower than GLC. BM can package this discount in various way, such as higher trade in or absolute discount from the listed price. When I was seriously considering NX before I test drove the GLC, I told the SE to give me the absolute final discounted price assuming I don't trade in my car. 
 
Cnc style is to put an absolute black and white figure on the OT and play around with lowballing your trade in price.
 
BM style is they tell you they don't do overtrades, but they will give you a trade in offer that is slightly above the other 2nd hand dealers' offer. To me it is just OT in disguise, just how you present it.
 
My advice for your friend (if he is still on the fence) will be to consider both cars on their own merits based on the final price and not to be confabulated by all the trade in/OT.
 
My final decision was easy when I ask myself this question: Will I be driving my NX/GLC and when I see another GLC/NX on the road, I will let go a sigh of regret?

FWIW, Dialmer AG FY earnings missed the analysts estimated, shared went down 4% in early trading today. Any additional earnings from GLC would have helped the €500 Millions missed at EBIT level.
 
Car buying cycle for consumers are much longer than mobile phones, once the consumer decided to buy another brand, he may not come back for a few years. Not to mention for the case of GLC, main competitors such as BMW X3 and Volvo XC60 should be launching new models soon. As far as I know, BMW X3 is the reference for medium size luxury SUV.

 
Actually, i think by suppressing supply in high demand area to avoid giving discounts thus increase margins per unit, i think is a smart move. The balance between inventory, production, demand and pricing is a fine balancing act. Producing too many and flood the inventory could potentially suppress pricing. 
 
You should be looking at the top line, i.e. revenue instead of EBITDA or EBIT if you're focusing on sales volume. Many other factors affects the bottom line, and even EBIT. There maybe asset revaluation and impairment which affects the depreciation and amortization before you arrive at EBIT. For operating performance, look at EBITDA, and their inventory and PPE from the balance sheet. There is also forex exposure to look at in the P+L if their big sales volume are exposed to high currency volatility countries, which in 2016, happens to be UK with the high depreciation of GBP compared to EURO, which is Daimler's reporting currency.

Hi Vratenza,
         Why you chose GLC amongst all the other models you mentioned above? I am curious to know, because I booked GLC already and did not test drive any of the above models other than the NX. Just wanted to know if I have made a good choice.

To be frank, since you booked GLC already, whether is a good choice or not does not matter much now. That question should have been asked before booking.
 
GLC is NOT the perfect car but it ticks the most items on my checklist for the car I want to drive. I will not go into the nitty gritty details...but these are some of the reasons why I did not choose the other models:
 
NX
- fussy japanese style interior
- aggressive manga type exterior looks
- Perm FWD part time AWD
- BM not sincere in retaining a former owner
 
old X3
- dated austere interior although quality is there
- handling while best in the class sacrifices comfort on long drives
- dated exterior
- stiff pricing from PML for EOL model
- weakest engine X3 20i for almost the same money as the german competitor. the equivalent power output performance X3 28i is easily 50K more
 
old XC60
- FWD
- firm and crashy suspension
- interior finish and quality mediocre
- looks dated as well
 
LR Disco Sport
- crap interior (design and fit and finish)....press on door panel can see the gap, creak and move kind
- decent power from engine but unrefined
 
old Q5
- decent handling
- power adequate...but don't like all those PA gimmick of giving you power upgrades after car arrives singapore.
 
 
F-pace
- interior quality almost like LR Disco Sports....same parent company, not surprised
- drive and handling is the best of all the candidate ( it might be competing with RX class instead)
- 2L Diesel engine alhough quite alright...but the supercharged 3L petrol is the one to go for but that pricing is in the macan territory.
 
 
End of the day, except for the F-Pace, GLC is the latest to the party and it shows in the overall design  with trademark MB quality.
GLC has always been viewed by many as just C-class on stilts but in fact the platform is a shortened E-class platform and is evident in the space it translate into.
 
Detractors can bring up many negative aspects of GLC (eg. the shorter rear bench thigh rest, the running boards obstructing ease of entry/exit, lack of carplay/GPS, lack of standard genuine leather)...but if you take a step back and look... are those things going to make or break a good car or is just nitpicking on an overall fine vehicle?

if you want to buy a car which you will not regret, then choose the one that you heart desire, not your head. ask yourself: which is the one that you will look forward to driving every morning??
 
no car is perfect, every car will have some feature lacking if compared to another.
 
But all these small differences which your head is weighing one against the other will be irrelevant when you own the car your heart wants.
 
your brain will give in to your heart and overlook at its shortcomings, and they wont bother you once you own it.
 
but if you buy the car that your head wants, your heart will come back to question your brain and that's the beginning of the regret process

I think I mountain tortoise.....but after some time with the MB Intelligent LED Light System that comes standard on CnC GLC, I find it quite impressive! 
 

 
 
http://techcenter.mercedes-benz.com/en/led_intelligent_light_system/detail.html
 
 

 
The LED Intelligent Light System offers a variety of adaptive light functions which automatically adapt the headlamps to typical driving and weather situations.
 
 
LED headlamps are closer to the daylight colour spectrum than xenon headlamps, for example, and are less tiring for the driver's eyes. There is no need to change the bulbs for the whole life of the vehicle.
 
Individual light functions:
 

Country mode and motorway mode replace dipped beam headlamps. Country mode illuminates the verge on the vehicle side more brightly and extensively than standard halogen dipped headlamps do. At speeds above 90 km/h, motorway mode is automatically activated, expanding the driver's visibility in two stages: first the performance of the LEDs increases, illuminating the road and the verges better. Then, at speeds above 110 km/h the range of the lamps is increased without dazzling the oncoming traffic.
 
The active light function swings the headlamps into bends by up to 15°, thus illuminating the road far better. This works in both dipped and full-beam mode.
 
The cornering light function improves the illumination of the road on corners and tight bends. Above a certain steering wheel angle, a module with two LEDs per headlamp is automatically activated on the appropriate side.
 
The extended foglamp reduces dazzle to the driver caused by light reflected by the fog and at the same time it illuminates the outer half of the road more brightly. To do so, the headlamp on the driver's side swings outwards by 8° and the light cone is lowered. The function can be activated at speeds of up to 70 km/h. If the driver subsequently accelerates to a speed of over 100 km/h, the extended foglamp switches off.
 
The rear lamps also have LED technology. In order not to dazzle following drivers, the brightness of the brake lamp varies according to the ambient light and is for example automatically dimmed at night at a red traffic light. In addition, together with the brake light, the surrounding light strips light up, further reducing the dazzling effect.
 
When the vehicle is stationary, the LED Intelligent Light System also provides the driver with improved comfort and safety: the "coming home" function is triggered by the key fob when the vehicle is opened or locked and lights the way to or from the vehicle.

The truth of the matter is this. MB principal only has oversight and control over their ADs. 
 
Singapore is a small market, so CnC is the only AD.
 
In the right hand drive countries like UK/HK, where those PI units are actually sourced from, our local PIs just buy the units off these foreign ADs showroom or buy off their allocated factory slots and ship them over to Singapore.
 
To MB principal, they only know that their cash register is ringing non-stop.....they do not really care if the cash register rings from Singapore or from UK/HK. And even if they care, they have no way to control what happens to their cars after leaving the ADs' parking lot.
 
The only way is when ah gong suddenly say that only ADs are allowed to import cars into Singapore.
 
But I do agree that being the sole AD in Singapore, CnC should have exerted some pressure on the principal to allocate them more production slots with data showing the sale numbers of PI GLCs compared to their own.

Add of adblue is designed to be between service intervals.
 
http://www.mercedes-benz.com.au/content/australia/mpc/mpc_australia__website/en/home_mpc/passengercars/home/service_parts/genuine_parts/lubricants_fluids/adblue.html
 	How often does AdBlue® need to be used?
 
The vehicle will not operate unless there is sufficient AdBlue® in the vehicle’s AdBlue® tank. The size of the AdBlue® tank has been designed so that a customer should not have to refill AdBlue® in between service intervals, however an individual vehicle’s AdBlue® consumption may be higher depending on operating conditions.On average, 1 litre of AdBlue® should last around 1,000km, however usage can be higher depending on how the vehicle is driven and the conditions that the vehicle is subjected to.• Every A Service AdBlue® tank is refilled / topped up• Every B Service AdBlue® tank is drained and refilledIf the amount of AdBlue® in the vehicle reaches the minimal level before an A or B Service, a message will appear on the instrument cluster.

Very complicated discussion but this is one of the more succinct explanation I read online from other forum (the reply is for someone asking if Adblue is better than DPF):
 
I think depending on vehicle application, the adblue allows the manufacturer to tune the diesel engine to run more efficiently.
 

 
 

Your choice is not DPF or AdBlue. All modern diesels will have a DPF. Your choice has to do with how Oxides of Nitrogen are handled. Lighter weight cars can get by with a NOx storage catalyst (Golf and Jetta), while heavier vehicles need (Passat, Mercedes, etc.) require an SCR (Selective Catalytic Reduction) system. SCR systems require a Urea (AdBlue) injection system. There are advantages and disadvantages to both as previously stated. SCR systems do not require post combustion fuel injections, but they do require AdBlue injections. 
 
 


Same for my BMW 216GT and that's why I don't understand why some diesels need to put adblue whilst other don't?

Hi 5!!!!

After owning and driving the GLC around for > 1 month, I think I can come up with a mini review of the GLC based on day to day ownership experience instead of the usual 1-test-drive by the showroom hoppers/1 day usage review by professional reviewers.
 
1. I am not sure if it is because of my 19" RFT fitted for my option, my GLC seems to come with individual TPM sensors which shows each individual tire's pressure in kPa. I was surprised as I had always thought GLC comes with ABS based "Software" TPMS. Just discovered this yesterday though 
 
2. CnC delivered the car with 290kPa pressure all round. I always thought the ride is pretty firm due to the 19" RFT and the AMG Line suspension. Going to try reduce to 260kPa later to try if it improves the pliancy when travelling in slow speed along uneven surfaced roads.
 
3. As mentioned earlier, I like the AMG Line suspension, combined with the 4matic, going round the bends and swiping curve is very reassuring with tons of grip and body sway control. Highway speed straight road, the suspension absorbs the surface irregularity perfectly.The only niggle is at low speed going about at carpark speed, all the road imperfections and undulation are transmitted to the cabin, ie. not very pliant at low speed.
 
4. ILS. If you never own it, you will not miss it. But once you have it, it is hard to go back on the normal static HID/LED. The way it brightens up the road is day and night when I compared it to my previous car's HID. at least 50% brighter and further compared on the same stretch of dimly lit road I travel daily going home. The swivel of the beams towards where your steering is pointed along a curve road as well as the cornering light on 90 degrees turn improves safety by a large margin as I can see further up the intended path. Pedestrians also seem to be aware that my car is turning due to the "unusual" swivelling of the light towards them and they tend to wait for me to finish my turn instead of trying to run across while I am turning. Secondarily, the ILS headlamps just look more chio. 
 
5. The driver seat of the GLC has one of the most adjustments I have come across, including a thigh support adjustment as well as lumbar support that can be adjusted 4 ways to get the support to the exact level along your lumbar spine. The downside to it is the side bolsters are too wide apart for the average asian male physique. During faster cornering and turns, can feel the sides of the lumbar region tending to slide to either side. Larger sized individual and AMDKs should have no problem with that.
 
6. The 2.0T mercedes engine is as smooth as any 4 potter TC engine you can get. Mated to the 9G-Tronic, the gear changes are almost imperceptible. There are occasions during low speed 1-2 gear change (eg, slowing down to almost a stop at traffic light and suddenly need to accelerate ast the light turned green) that result in a rougher than usual shift as it was caught flatfooted so to speak. 
 
7. The drive modes are surprisingly useful despite only able to change the engine/transmission response, the steering firmness, SSS and aircon mode. The Sports+ can be pretty aggressive and not meant for day to day kind of driving. My go to setting is set in Individual customizable mode where I just choose the same setting as Sports mode but just deactivate the SSS.
 
8. The start stop system in the GLC is crap to say the least. In our hot climate, the SSS can restart the engine within minutes from stopping as the interior temperature is detected to raise beyond a certain threshold. within a traffic light stop duration, I think there was quite a few times that it had to restart even before the traffic light turns green. Much much worse in traffic jams.
 
And the re-starting of the engine is quite perceptible (compared to say a 2009 Lexus GS450h, well it is a 3.5L V6 NA, so maybe it is unfair as comparison), such that after a few days of trying to see if I can live with it, I turned it off every time these days.
 
9. The road noise and sound insulation of the GLC is pretty good I must say.  And I am comparing it with the noise and road noise insulation of a Lexus GS hybrid running on 18" rims. Just make sure the model you get comes with front side double-glazed window glass (some region do not have this double glaze glass).
 
10. CnC unit only specced with Audio 20 and not prewired for GPS/SD card. My SE threw in an after market GPS system that is touch screen operated (think they swapped out the original Audio 20 screen for a touch screen). Not the most intuitive but getting the hang of the operations and I can easily assess the items I want with the swivel knob pretty quickly after a while. The touchpad is alright but functions better as a palm rest while I use the swivel knob 
 
11. The Audio 20 comes with only 1 CD slot, but I do no miss those multiCD changers since it comes wit 2X USB port accessible via the center armrest compartment. I got a 32gb low profile USB3.0 thumbdrive, transfer the whole of my iTune lbrary (12GB) into it and plugged it in and forget about it. The Audio 20 system is able to read the Chinese characters and also display the album cover for each of the songs as what appears on the iTune player on the PC/Mac.
 
12. The 2X USB ports are 0.5A specced, so charging modern day mobile phones and tablets are going to be a pain in the ass. So I advised to get those 2.1A cigerate lighter socket powered adapter for fast charging on the move.
 
13. The factory speaker setup is already quite sufficient, able to tune the base, treble and mids. Can adjust the staging as well but must say the staging effect is not as defined as my lexus mark levinson. This is very subjective though, your mileage might vary.
 
14. Cnc units comes with interior dash and door trim stitching. if you add the AMG Line option, the stitching is retained. The PI AMG Line units I saw, the stitchings are replaced by plain vanilla non-stitched surface. A step down in terms of luxury/quality feel. Those in the market please keep an eye out for that when shopping or negotiating.
 
15. The panoroof is a must especially if you have black on black interior with black roof liner.  How it opens up the space with simply unrolling the fabric shield can only be experienced in person. 
 
16. The running boards takes some getting use to but it does help in maybe preventing some potential dings as I saw most sedans have their door lower edge lower than the running boards level, not going help for SUVS/lorry/vans though. It is a boon for my kid to climb up and down the car on his own.
 
17. The amount of interior storage is huge. Just need to get a centre armrest compartment divider to organize the space better. The rear space without spare tire allows alot of inferequently used stuff to disappear from the boot, thereby freeing up a fully usable load carrying space. Love the fact that the tonneaue cover is retractable along a guide rail and can be stored under the floor board when not in use. Some SUVs in the market do not come with that function.
 
18. The hands-free booth opening is very reliable once you get the hang of the kicking motion required and where to kick.
 
19. have not tried auto-park feature yet.
 
20. Traffic light HOLD brake function is useful for the lazy right leg during city traffic and highway jams.
 
 
Will add on later if I thought of something.

You will not get AMG Line with brown leather/artico interior because the AMG Line flat bottom "D-shaped"  sports steering wheel do not come in brown. Most PI will not take the risk of bringing in a frankly mismatched interior. If you want to put in a factory build order with PI,  might as well go with C&C. 
 
Same as heated steering wheel is not available with AMG Line since they don't make those in sports steering style. 
 
For those interested to know, the difference between the normal steering and the AMG Line steering:
 
-both diameter more or less the same
-obviously one is O-shape and the other is D-shaped
- normal steering is smooth artico leather bound throughout. 
- AMG Line steering has leather perforation in the 3 and 9 o'clock position for better grip
- AMG Line steering is thicker thoughout compared to the normal steering
- AMG line center "T" section has more brushed chrome effect trim
- the paddle shifters are black and smaller in size compared to the brushed chrome ones on the AMG Line steering.

Comfort depends on what you are looking for and individual preference.
 
I like my ride to be firm but with good body sway control. That is my definition of comfort. Those soft/standard suspension that bounce and lean too much gives me motion sickness, especially in a tall vehicle like an SUV.
 
Compared to my test drive experience of the standard GLC suspension on 18" non-RFT last year, I prefer the AMG Line's suspension on 19" RFT. The stock standard GLC ride is not bad but leaning towards being a bit soft for my preference.
 
It was a leap of faith when I ordered the AMG line option without a test drive but lucky for me, the sportier firmer ride is just what I wanted (might be even better when I get to swap out to 19" non-RFT)

Reading other countries' merc forum, seem like abnormally high tire pressure for cars shipped from the merc factory is standard.
 
My theory for the reason being that the high tire pressures help to make the cars more stable during the shipping on the RORO ship. It reduces the sideway movements during rough sea and thus less damage to repair once the car reach destination.

	Edited June 6, 2017 by Davidtch

According to my manual, GLC petrol is minimum 95RON. 
 
But noted this interesting footnote on GLC300 (same 4potter turbo as GLC250 but in higher tune) and GLC450AMG (renamed to GLC 43 AMG, which is  6 potter twin turbo) 
 
 
 

Only refuel using super unleaded petrol with at least 98 ROZ, if you want maximum performance from the engine. Alternatively, you can also use unleaded petrol of at least 95 ROZ.
As a temporary measure, if the recommended fuel is not available, you may also use regular unleaded petrol with an octane rating of 91 ROZ. Doing so results in higher fuel consumption and significantly reduced performance. Never refuel using fuel with a lower RON.
Fuel of this specification may contain up to 10% ethanol.
Fuel that does not conform to EN 228 or E DIN 51626–1 can lead to increased wear as well as damage to the engine and exhaust system.
 

So contrary to what some people alluded to, a higher RON than minimum stated does translate to better performance from the engine.

According to my manual, GLC petrol is minimum 95RON. 
 
But noted this interesting footnote on GLC300 (same 4potter turbo as GLC250 but in higher tune) and GLC450AMG (renamed to GLC 43 AMG, which is  6 potter twin turbo) 
 
 
 
 
So contrary to what some people alluded to, a higher RON than minimum stated does translate to better performance from the engine. 

 
Only if you have a performance engine. Basically, the engine has a maximum performance. Minimum stated may be RON 95 but it might not run at full efficiency/power. Hence the ability to "unlock" more power by using higher RON petrol.
 
But if you only have a normal engine, typically minimum is only 92. Using 95 might give a bit more power but unlikely upgrading further to 98 or more will add any more power.

Yeah, different engines will have different baseline fuel maps (minimum RON) with one grade higher better performance fuel map when better fuel is available and one grade lower fuel map for emergency detuned state to protect the engine from detonation(knocking)  damage when suboptimal RON fuel is detected. 
 
Of course, turbo engines tend to have more bandwidth to push the air-fuel-timing envelope further than NA engines.

Yesterday, borrowed the GLC Coupe 250d from my bro to test drive. Drove to fetch my fren and to the usual field I go to fly r/c.
 
- the torque is amazing, the pull from the turbo diesel power plant is something I never felt before when I floor the throttle at traffic light sprints.
- however at lower speed, the gear change is a little bit jerky, unlike my current CVT gearbox car.
- at cruising highway speed, gearbox was silky smooth, no noticeable gear change and went up to D8, cruising at 90km/h @ 1,500rpm.
- slow speed(normal pickup), engine noise was audible.
- tyre noise was also audible at cruising speed of 90km/h @ 1,500rpm, just like my car running on runflat tyres.
- suspension was towards the stiff end.
- no noticeable body roll at turns or bends, felt totally planted to the ground.
- interior space was ok, no problem for my fren(ard 1.8m) sitting behind at all. Still have 3 to 4 finger spacing to the front seat and 5 finger spacing to the roof. My frens all say they are comfortable.
- flat bottom steering wheel and the thickness of the grip was just nice.
- sitting position was not too high up, felt comfortable.
- the seats just hug your body, maybe its me too fat.
- centre arm rest is very deep, can keep lots of stuff.
- I never fiddle the entertainment system, just listen to radio.
- This car can really get me into trouble with TP. Got to really feather the throttle!!! And watch the speedometer.
 
 
- lacking of windscreen wiper stock, had a hard time looking. Its incorporated into the light switch.
- hazard light(or as Malaysians call it, double signal light) was so tiny and in the same line as the entertainment switches.
- speedometer on the left instead of the right.
- rear window very small and rear quarter is a huge blindspot when comes to parking.
- the diesel engine noise was loud on the outside, but cannot be heard on the inside when it is idling.
- boot space, sufficient for everyday use but not for me. Prefer my deep boot stationwagon.

Because the centre armrest compartment is so deep and cavernous, I recommend your brother to get this cheap add on to manage the space better. The smaller, more often access stuff can be organized on top and the bigger less frequently used stuff at the bottom.

 
 
The GLC coupe's rear boot space should also have a hidden shallow storage space under the floor board. That is useful for smaller frequently need to be carried around but not often used items, eg. spare tissue packets, birdshit wet wipes, load securing ratcheting straps, first aid kits

 

Yesterday, borrowed the GLC Coupe 250d from my bro to test drive. Drove to fetch my fren and to the usual field I go to fly r/c.
 
- the torque is amazing, the pull from the turbo diesel power plant is something I never felt before when I floor the throttle at traffic light sprints.
- however at lower speed, the gear change is a little bit jerky, unlike my current CVT gearbox car.
- at cruising highway speed, gearbox was silky smooth, no noticeable gear change and went up to D8, cruising at 90km/h @ 1,500rpm.
- slow speed(normal pickup), engine noise was audible.
- tyre noise was also audible at cruising speed of 90km/h @ 1,500rpm, just like my car running on runflat tyres.
- suspension was towards the stiff end.
- no noticeable body roll at turns or bends, felt totally planted to the ground.
- interior space was ok, no problem for my fren(ard 1.8m) sitting behind at all. Still have 3 to 4 finger spacing to the front seat and 5 finger spacing to the roof. My frens all say they are comfortable.
- flat bottom steering wheel and the thickness of the grip was just nice.
- sitting position was not too high up, felt comfortable.
- the seats just hug your body, maybe its me too fat.
- centre arm rest is very deep, can keep lots of stuff.
- I never fiddle the entertainment system, just listen to radio.
- This car can really get me into trouble with TP. Got to really feather the throttle!!! And watch the speedometer.
 
 
- lacking of windscreen wiper stock, had a hard time looking. Its incorporated into the light switch.
- hazard light(or as Malaysians call it, double signal light) was so tiny and in the same line as the entertainment switches.
- speedometer on the left instead of the right.
- rear window very small and rear quarter is a huge blindspot when comes to parking.
- the diesel engine noise was loud on the outside, but cannot be heard on the inside when it is idling.
- boot space, sufficient for everyday use but not for me. Prefer my deep boot stationwagon.

I test drove the C&C GLC before placing my booking. That is before they even have a display unit at the showroom. The test drive car was also their "display" car for those who expressed interest to view. 
 
The 2.0T and the 9G-tronic does wonder to the drive of this 1.8ton vehicle. The 9 gear ratio with it's closed spaced and wide spread allows the MB engineers to tune the 2.0T such that the max torque of 350nm arrives at 1200rpm. The engine vibration is well Insulated by the chassis sound damping and insulation. Front double glazed windows helps in no small part. Gear change is almost imperceptible and the only clue u have that the gear changed is the info cluster gear indicator and the raise/fall of the rpm. Gear 2 is uncharacteristically "rougher" than all the other gears but seem to improve after running in and the transmission learns the driving style. 
 
The start stop system is not the smoothest. Still cannot get used to the engine start jerk each time so it is toggled off for every drive.

When the hybrid battery fails, can the car still be driven? 
I'm under the impression that the petrol drivetrain takes over completely in the event the hybrid system fails.

Ahemmm....what ppl do w their wrist until need to rest har? LOL...
 
My left wrist is usually resting on a slim svelte thigh.

When the hybrid battery fails, can the car still be driven?
 
I'm under the impression that the petrol drivetrain takes over completely in the event the hybrid system fails.
Apparently it is one of the complex series of power control chips that fail causing the recharging of the hybrid battery to be inefficient. 
The system limits the normal power delivery and the "Power Hybrid" mode cannot be activated. A sort of "Limp Home" mode. Still drivable just not shiok. The BM SA reassure me that safety is not an issue...... 
 
They eventually just swapped out the control modules with a brand new hybrid battery under the extended +2hrs warranty.(they claim insurance anyway)  I suspect they don't have local expertise to just change the failed chip and troubleshoot. 
 
Anyway, even if the hybrid system totally fail, the 3.5L V6 petrol is no slouch either, just don't have the go-cart kind of instant torque.

The $3600 goes towards some hardware changes like an internally mounted gps receiver, SD card slot in the center armrest console. Yes, still exorbitant, but that is factory fitted and LTA takes a large chunk of of it too. 
 
Imho, the Garmin is still a Garmin, nothing fancy, and from the online reviews of the system, the interface is even less intuitive than the physical Garmin standalone units due to the lack touchscreen function. 
 
You are better off trying to ask for locally fitted:
-front rear car cam,
-3rd party GPS unit that C&C claims is worth about $2k (highly doubt it),
-6k service credit (or more if u can),
-huper optik film,  
-STAR package (think quite standard with car nano coatings, some free pick pickup and drop off service) 
 
Most important aspect of getting all these from. C&C is that your warranty is intact and the vendors warranty are honored.

If you need to load and unload wheelchairs on daily basis, SUVs are not what you should be looking at. The loading height is higher than most other vehicle. So it will be quite a chore.
 
Look at station wagons (A6 Avant, C/E wagons, 5 series wagons) , for a better fit for your needs.
 
 
 
Check out this practicality review for those interested in how much space GLC SUV has and if it suits your needs. 
 


 
Actually for my bro and I, we find that loading and unloading of wheelchair, a SUV is perfect for us. The loading height is just nice. Also we need to carry my mum into the back seat. A SUV height is really easier for us.
 
I tried with my saloon(i45) and stationwagon(A6 Avant), my back hurts and had great difficulty transferring my mum from wheelchair to back seat. Yes, either cars swallow the whole wheelchair with ease but the loading height is a killer. Therefore, my next ride might be an SUV.
 
The GLC Coupe has no problem fitting my mum's wheelchair in the boot.

IIRC you are pretty tall , 1.8 - 1.9m? That may explain why since you cannot really straighten your back (and knees half bent) while loading and unloading wheelchairs in the sedans/SW. Your lower back muscles are always in tension throughout the range of motion of loading and unloading the wheelchairs. Same goes for helping your mother to and from the vehicle and the wheelchair. In your case I believe SUVs works well. But for more average height person, the higher loading sill will mean having to haul the wheelchair much higher and thus potentially straining the lower back as the person gave a harder jerk to clear the load of the sill.
 
I am not that tall, but one of the reason I chose to go with SUV this round is on bad days, I can't even get out of my previous sedan's driver seat after a long drive. Had to to literally pull myself out from the seat using the door frame as leverage.

From my understanding, because the sources of cars for the PI are very varied. Some UK specs, some HK specs, from UK dealers, from HK dealers. Each might also bring in same exact optioned models from different sources.
 
LTA treats each car as a separate entity when it comes to PI cars. Not that they are hardworking and wants to work more for the ones doing homologation. Rather it is too much effort to match all the vehicle codes with the various factory option codes of the cars from various sources. So in a way, just blanket homologate all PI sources.
 
Whereas for ADs, they have only 1 source of cars, and that is from the manufacturer themselves. The models they bring in are very consistent and in large quantiies and thus LTA can just homologate all of them by batches. Only those special indents with unusual options will need to be homologated on arrival. For eg. my car has pano+AMG Line option, because it has previously been ordered in this combination, I do not need to go through homologation. I did ask before, if I add in a further Driving Assistance Package what will happen, my SE checked and told me that it will delay the registration by about a month because this combination has not been brought in before, thus need homologation.

Tall high CG cars like SUVs will benefit from a wide wheel tracks and full time AWD to help with lowering the CG and improving stability. 
 
Have to really own a full time AWD vehicle for a period longer than a test drive duration to appreciate the benefit and assurance it gives. If one is sensitive enough to what goes on between the tires and the road, one don't need to drive like a hooligan to appreciate the nuances in maximum grip afforded by a real full time AWD. 
 
For those with the opportunity to take one AWD vehicle for a spin, just try powering up or down one of those curve joining ramps of expressways eg. ECP, down ramp of the Benjamin Sheares towards Suntec.
 
For RWD cars, especially those with high torque, try accelerating after the rear wheels pass a hump on a wet day, see how quickly your ESP kicks in to cut power to your rear wheels. Now try again with a full time AWD vehicle on the same stretch accelerating.
 
These are just some of the tangible benefit of a full time AWD over RWD/FWD in daily non-hooligan driving situations.
 
Then again, just like how some drivers appreciate Altis/Vezel as a good car because it brings them from point A to B without excitement or fuss, there will be a group of drivers who cannot appreciate the real world difference among RWD/FWD/AWD vehicle. 
 
So, no point in spending more for something you do not appreciate or can harness the benefit. Just like I don't see a need to spend my money on rolex or cigars simply because I don't know how to appreciate them.

A person's selection for car can be related to Maslow Law.
Physiological - A Bread and Butter car for Point A to Point B will do
Safety - Slightly better and Safer car
Social Need - Need a car which people can relate, not just a B&B safe car
Esteem - Need a car that can boost my esteem
Self Actuation - I need a powerful car!!! 5 Wheels drive (Including spare tyre also must drive!)
 
Enojy your Friday guys! Be safe!

Just discovered something about the GLC's AT (I guess it applied to most Merc across the range). 
 
Paddle shifters/manual over-ride
 
The function most people will have no problem using is simply, left paddle pull once to drop one gear, right paddle pull once to up one gear.
 
While in any D gear, if you pull and hold the left paddle shift for a while longer, the transmission will drop the gear to a gear (maybe a few gears down given the current count is 9)  that is optimal for your current speed. I have yet to bring my car up north, as I think it might be more useful at higher speed and longer stretches of highway, so I have not been able to test it out personally.
 
When you are in manual mode (because you have previously down-shifted using the left paddle), and you want to hand the control back to the auto transmission, you can:
1) pull and hold the right paddle for a short duration
or
2) tap the steering mounted gear shifter down (towards D) once
 
........and you will see that the Mx will change to Dx in your instrument panel.
 
Previously I had always have to up-shift manually and wait for the AT to take over the reign after I was done with the manual down-shift to enter a bend at a slightly higher speed.
 
Hope this information will find use for other GLC/Merc owners here.

Anyone knows how long it takes for C&C from car arrival at port to key handover?

Depends if you added any fancy uncommon combinations of options. If your combination have not been brought in by C&C previously, your delivery might add another 1month to clear homologation at LTA. 
 
If need not undergo homologation, about 1.5 to 2 weeks is reasonable depends on how on the ball your SE is in getting your final cheque ( mine came to my place to collect the cheque) for them to process the registration and prepping the car. 
 
C&C will have all the just shipped in car do final check through by their technician before passing their internal QC standard... about 1-2 working days. If you have window film, maybe add 0.5 to 1 day, 3rd party GPS add 1day, nanocoating (if you choose to do one session before delivery is 0.5 to 1 day. See those half days? It depends on how well your SE can squeeeze in those half days together to minimise the delay. 
 
End of day, best person to ask will be your SE.

To be absolutely honest...... 
 
If I am looking at FC, SUV or the likes should not be on my shopping list.
 
If I am looking to save on wear and tear, a toyota with it's extensive market dominance and parts availability will be a better choice.
 
If I am looking a premium category car, I will just enjoy the car as it is. I leave all the preflight and post flight checks to the pilots. 
 
I switch my drive mode to my individualised setting each and everytime i start the car:
ASS off
Engine Sports
Transmission Sports
Aircon normal
 
I leave the sports+ drive mode for the occasional "spirited" driving when roads are clear. 
 
My only complaint will be that MB do not allow for preferred drive mode to be memorised. Well, it's MB wide, so I guess just have to suck it up.

Have to clarify a bit... 
It’s impossible to have a fair comparison as PI models come as it is, anything else is locally modified. For me, the price difference on paper was about $23k. However, the PI config varies and many can’t really confirm the features until the car is shipped out of the ADs in UK or HK that they buy from. In general, I can’t find these features which I value:
1) Ambient lights - really nice feature
2) side floor boards - some have some don’t
3) ILS LED lights - most PI model don’t or can’t confirm. Was told this is quite expensive.
4) I wanted the 360 camera which I think is reasonable for $1,500 from AD. Very few PIs can offer this or have to do local install.
5) $5k service credit from AD
 
So, I estimate if I nego from PI down another $5k, gap would only be $15k. Rather subjective, I know. In the end, I would rather wait 6 months to get the exact config that I want then compromise. Tough long wait though. Mine is the GLC coupe btw.
 
When u say AMG, not sure what u mean. Coupe comes with the AMG kit... love the diamond grills! All cosmetics though... far away from the real AMG 43 and AMG 63.

Don't believe everything the PI says.
 
- 19" is RFT and they takes out the tire repair kit. 18" is nonRFT with tire repair kit.
- Stiffer Sports suspension comes standard on AMG-lines. Slightly lower in ride height. Approx 1cm difference only.
- AMG logoed car mats.
- there is no AMG badge for AMG line.
 
You should compare specs for specs. The interior trims have different versions, some with dash stitching some don't. Some interior mood lighting, some don't. Check out how much is the ILS option with the PI. Have a GLC owner bought from PI, the car don't come with the collision prevention assist feature which I had thought is standard baseline feature (apparently not).
Just pretend you are ready to order through them but insist on optioning in the ILS. See how much you have to pay for just that feature alone. Only then you get the real price difference.
 
Enjoy the research and buying process!

Collision Prevention Assist plus comes with active brake assist. Effectively means that there will be front sensors that will visually warn you if you are following too closely and loud audio warning if it detects that your distance to the car in front is closing rapidly or the front car's brake light flashed. The active braking will intervene if the system determine that collision is iminent. 
 
So far I have only managed to trigger the audio warning, very useful. Thankfully I have not experienced the active braking.

he competitor of CnC

Any GLC owners with engine check light with code:P0128 to take note of my experience.
 
The P0128 is related to the engine temperature not reaching the optimal temperature within a set time limit. Online research seem to point towards a faulty radiator thermostat that is stuck in open position.
 
Had 1st encounter 4 months or so into ownership, brought back to CnC, was told is due to firmware issue, so they flashed new firmware and all was good till another 6 months down the road when it happened a second time.
 
Brought it back to CnC, demand an explanation as to why a supposedly firmware issue can be recurrent despite having had it flashed previously. I was told that Merc Benz SOP is such that they still need to flash newer firmware to troubleshoot the problem for my 2017 production model. Apparently if it is a 2018 model, they will just change the thermostat without question. Thus my car was held for 2.5days for them to reflash the firmware and eventually they decided to just change the radiator thermostat for me.
 
After the repair, took my car up to Port Dickson /Malacca/JB for 5 days trip. So far no issue. Keeping my finger cross as the previous "reflash" only lasted me 6 months. 
 
So if you encounter similar error code, I suggest you demand for a change in thermostat instead of just an update of firmware, which I believe to be just kicking the can down the road.
 
Ps:I have an OBDII reader so am able to self check what is the error code related to the engine check light before sending it in.
This engine check light will go off after a number of restart of engine but CnC should be able to dig into the Ecu for record of the error codes.

Any GLC owners with engine check light with code:P0128 to take note of my experience.
 
The P0128 is related to the engine temperature not reaching the optimal temperature within a set time limit. Online research seem to point towards a faulty radiator thermostat that is stuck in open position.
 
Had 1st encounter 4 months or so into ownership, brought back to CnC, was told is due to firmware issue, so they flashed new firmware and all was good till another 6 months down the road when it happened a second time.
 
Brought it back to CnC, demand an explanation as to why a supposedly firmware issue can be recurrent despite having had it flashed previously. I was told that Merc Benz SOP is such that they still need to flash newer firmware to troubleshoot the problem for my 2017 production model. Apparently if it is a 2018 model, they will just change the thermostat without question. Thus my car was held for 2.5days for them to reflash the firmware and eventually they decided to just change the radiator thermostat for me.
 
After the repair, took my car up to Port Dickson /Malacca/JB for 5 days trip. So far no issue. Keeping my finger cross as the previous "reflash" only lasted me 6 months. 
 
So if you encounter similar error code, I suggest you demand for a change in thermostat instead of just an update of firmware, which I believe to be just kicking the can down the road.
 
Ps:I have an OBDII reader so am able to self check what is the error code related to the engine check light before sending it in.
This engine check light will go off after a number of restart of engine but CnC should be able to dig into the Ecu for record of the error codes.
Although I don’t own/drive a GLC but I’m sure those who does will appreaciate you sharing this.

Facelift coming.
 	2019 Mercedes-Benz GLC-Class spied with familiar refreshhttps://www.autoblog.com/2018/07/03/2019-mercedes-benz-glc-class-facelift-spy-photos/
 


The current Mercedes-Benz GLC-Class was revealed about three years ago for the 2016 model year, so it's about time for a midcycle refresh, which Mercedes appears to be working on. Spy photos reveal a lightly tweaked GLC luxury crossover SUV in testing. The main changes appear to be in the front fascia.Up front, the most obvious change is in the headlights. They have been changed to match the design set by the CLS-Class and AMG GT models. As such, the lower outside corners dip down, and the upper corners aren't as tall and upswept. Looking closer also reveals that the grille has also been revised. The bottom of the grille is a little smoother, and the outside corners have been stretched outward a bit.The rest of the car looks pretty much carryover. The taillights are covered up, which indicates that the lighting elements have likely been reworked, but any changes will be minimal. Otherwise, it's pretty much the same old GLC-Class.Considering how mild a refresh this is, we would expect it to be fully revealed within a year, likely in time for the 2019 model year.Engines will likely be carryover, which means the use of a turbocharged four-cylinder for the normal GLC300 models and the hybridGLC350e. There will almost certainly still be an AMG GLC43 with a twin-turbo V6 and an AMG GLC63 with a twin-turbo V8, too.

Thank you Bros in advance …

Congrats.
C&C units default use Huper Optik. You can enquire with them.

IMHO, the window films shluld be the least of your worries.
 
If I read correctly, you are intending to indent from factory through a PI? It will take months and if the PI close shop and run road during the interim, there is nothing you can do about it. Key to buying from PI is: Ready Stock. 
 
Back to your film question: yes, vkool uses the metallic sputter technology so signals will be affected and a cut out is required at the IU. Huper Optik and 3M uses non-metallic heat rejection method, so no IU cut out is required and phone GPS signal is unaffected. Good thing is, 
Whatever you choose, you can always redo it if you are unhappy with the result. 
 
Good luck!

Use the "long press" unlock button to activate the cabin heat venting program: the side windows and panoroof (if equipped) will retract to let the hot air out  while you are outside the car. 
 
After enter the car, once you are ready to close up, just "long press and hold" the internal/external circulation toggle switch to activate the tunnel mode for all the windows and panoroof to close up simultaneously. Save you the hassle of closing each one individually.

Good day Bro Vratenza,
 
Yes, it will take approximately 6 months (or maybe more) to get the car on the road via indent basis.  However, I feel it is worth the wait to have the car equipped with the options that I want direct from the factory.  
 
Thank you for your concern and advice regarding making an indent purchase via PI.  I myself have also thought long and hard about it.  However after doing some research, I am pretty confident that the PI which I am gonna place an order will fulfill their end of the deal.  This PI has been around for years and is pretty reputable.  Moreover, who is to say and assure that C&C may not also just close shop one day?  How can we forget the JP Morgan case a few years back?  Or that AIA and Citibank once also faced bankruptcy if not for the intervention from governments? LOL  
 
Why I choose to make an indent purchase from a PI is because I feel that C&C is not interested in doing indent purchase.  I spoke to a few of their SEs on different occasions and all of them look very disinterested to serve me after finding out that I may want to do an indent.  Although there are many options one can choose to add onto their GLC250 based on the brochure from C&C, the SEs were quick to highlight that there are certain options which they are not keen to indent.  One being the "automatic panoramic sliding sunroof".  Some may say that it is silly to have the panoramic sunroof as one will seldom use it in such a hot country like Singapore.  However since it is going to be my car and I am paying for it, should I not be the one to decide what I want?  
 
Luckily, I got to know a SE from one of the PIs who is not only patient in listening to what I want.  But he is also always ready to find out if he can get it for me and at what costs.  Moreover, he is not pushy and he always attend to me with a superb attitude although I have been deliberating for months.  He never once show any negative attitude even though I told him that I am still thinking and making comparisons with other PIs and C&C.
 
Back to the solar film:  I understand that V-Kool uses the metallic splutter technology and so am concerned that it may affect cell phone reception or wireless devices.  However, it is stated on V-Kool's website that it will have no effect on these devices.  But I wonder if Bros who has V-Kool on their cars can share their experiences?  
 
3M and Huber Optik utilizes ceramic technology in their solar films and these ceramic absorb the heat rather than reflecting it away.  Hence, one may feel their window panes heating up if they are to touch it during a hot and sunny day.
 
I agree that I can always redo it if I am unhappy with the result of my choice.  However, I will prefer to first make an informed decision rather than having to spend unnecessary time, money and effort in going down to the workshop later to replace it.

Thank you for your concern and advice regarding making an indent purchase via PI.  I myself have also thought long and hard about it.  However after doing some research, I am pretty confident that the PI which I am gonna place an order will fulfill their end of the deal.  This PI has been around for years and is pretty reputable.  Moreover, who is to say and assure that C&C may not also just close shop one day?  How can we forget the JP Morgan case a few years back?  Or that AIA and Citibank once also faced bankruptcy if not for the intervention from governments? LOL  
 
Why I choose to make an indent purchase from a PI is because I feel that C&C is not interested in doing indent purchase.  I spoke to a few of their SEs on different occasions and all of them look very disinterested to serve me after finding out that I may want to do an indent.  Although there are many options one can choose to add onto their GLC250 based on the brochure from C&C, the SEs were quick to highlight that there are certain options which they are not keen to indent.  One being the "automatic panoramic sliding sunroof".  Some may say that it is silly to have the panoramic sunroof as one will seldom use it in such a hot country like Singapore.  However since it is going to be my car and I am paying for it, should I not be the one to decide what I want?  
 
Luckily, I got to know a SE from one of the PIs who is not only patient in listening to what I want.  But he is also always ready to find out if he can get it for me and at what costs.  Moreover, he is not pushy and he always attend to me with a superb attitude although I have been deliberating for months.  He never once show any negative attitude even though I told him that I am still thinking and making comparisons with other PIs and C&C.
 
Back to the solar film:  I understand that V-Kool uses the metallic splutter technology and so am concerned that it may affect cell phone reception or wireless devices.  However, it is stated on V-Kool's website that it will have no effect on these devices.  But I wonder if Bros who has V-Kool on their cars can share their experiences?  
 
3M and Huber Optik utilizes ceramic technology in their solar films and these ceramic absorb the heat rather than reflecting it away.  Hence, one may feel their window panes heating up if they are to touch it during a hot and sunny day.
 
I agree that I can always redo it if I am unhappy with the result of my choice.  However, I will prefer to first make an informed decision rather than having to spend unnecessary time, money and effort in going down to the workshop later to replace it.

No issue for me too. One of my previous cars was on Vkool as well.

But what’s your wheels specs? 9x20 ET? 10x20 ET? Still felt that you could have used 265/45 and 295/40

9x20 ET 30
10x20 ET 35
 
265/45 with the larger rolling diameter and wider tire width, higher risk of front fender rub on the normal track width GLC.  If you read up on GLC, a portion of owners esp those with >20" rims have front tire crabbing issues. Don't want to risk that. (you can google "GLC Crabbing") 
 
295/40 shouldn't be a problem fitting but will have larger rolling diameter resulting in speedo under reading.
 
Overall I also have to balance all these factors:
- lateral stability (wider the better)
- rolling resistance (wider will be higher)
- steering responsiveness (narrower contact patch more precise)
- total wheel weight (rim+ tire) (heavier will increase unsprung weight leading to the lousier suspension performance and acceleration) 
- running cost ( wider tires more expensive to change when worn) 
- Common tire sizes (more common, wider choice of replacement brand and models) 
 
It is not exact science other than just satisfying the tire/rim spec calculator's recommended sizes. Alot is also trial and error along the way. I might have been wrong with my initial choice, as long as it is still safe to drive, I will learn from the current choice and hopefully improve on my tire/rim choice algorithm in the future.

You are right on the devil being in the details. 
 
I shall skip the obvious stuff which most 
people can rattle off like the amg line, panoroof, comfort access, leather, burmeister, distronic packages, 360 surround view, park assist etc... 
 
PI's GLC 250 most are just LED and not the ILS that C&C 200 comes with. How much is the difference, I am not sure.. But i bet that is enough meat for PI to keep bringing in LED instead of ILS to play the low cost "high spec" game to confuse the buyer. 
 
C&C GLCs comes with laminated acoustic glass for the front side windows to reduce wind noise. Elsewhere in the world, this acoustic glass is option item. 
 
C&C GLCs comes with on TPMS with on wheel sensors to read each tires pressure in real time. Elsewhere there are GLCs fitted with just ABS based sensors. 
 
These are just some of the details that most prospective GLC buyers would not have known unless they research into GLC as thoroughly as me.... 
 
So the price difference might be even smaller if you factor in the stuff I mentioned above. 
 
Not wrong to buy from PI. Just make sure you do your homework (and I mean a thorough one) and understand what you are trading off on for a cheaper price.

For insurance i will get quotation from my friend. Then show to dealer ask them to match my price since its same policy same insurer. Normally i was quoted double by car dealerHi Bro Thaiyotakamli, 
Actually, it is not true that the policy will be the same coming from the same insurer.  This is because certain dealers will have a special tie-up with their insurer to provide special policy unique to their own dealership.
 
For example, I know a case whereby a dealer has tied up with a certain insurer such that policies taken from the dealer itself will allow owners to have their cars repaired at workshops of their own choice including back at the dealership itself. As long as the customers are to renew their insurance policies thru the dealer, they can bring the car back to the dealer for repair or other workshops of their choice for the first 10 years of the car.
 
However, one will not be able to get the same policy by directly approaching the insurer. The policy direct from the insurer maybe slightly cheaper but cars that are more than 2 years old can only go for repairs at the insurer's authorized workshops.
 
Due to the slight difference in policy's premium, most (if not all) car owners will choose to renew their car insurance policies thru the dealer.
 
I believe this is a strategic alliance between the dealer and the insurer. This is because car owners will definitely be lured by the fact that they can continue to go back to the dealer for repairs even when their cars are old. This is beneficial to the dealer as they will have a decent income from owners going back there for their repairs. As for the insurer, they will continue to have the owners of these cars getting their policies indirectly from them. If not, the insurer may lose these car owners to their competitors.

For example, I know a case whereby a dealer has tied up with a certain insurer such that policies taken from the dealer itself will allow owners to have their cars repaired at workshops of their own choice including back at the dealership itself. As long as the customers are to renew their insurance policies thru the dealer, they can bring the car back to the dealer for repair or other workshops of their choice for the first 10 years of the car.
 
However, one will not be able to get the same policy by directly approaching the insurer. The policy direct from the insurer maybe slightly cheaper but cars that are more than 2 years old can only go for repairs at the insurer's authorized workshops.
 
Due to the slight difference in policy's premium, most (if not all) car owners will choose to renew their car insurance policies thru the dealer.
 
I believe this is a strategic alliance between the dealer and the insurer. This is because car owners will definitely be lured by the fact that they can continue to go back to the dealer for repairs even when their cars are old. This is beneficial to the dealer as they will have a decent income from owners going back there for their repairs. As for the insurer, they will continue to have the owners of these cars getting their policies indirectly from them. If not, the insurer may lose these car owners to their competitors.

I am exactly in the same situation like u mentioned.  But much analysis (both tangibles and intangibles) 
 
1.  If I sell my car on my own fetch higher price, but buyer want my car now and new GLC comes in Dec .  For 4 months I have no car .  If i go rent a car, the cost ?  
 
2.  Sell my car on my own higher price, but I lost out to over trade 
 
3.  Intangible benefits the more u gave to C&C , example trade in to them w over trade, and leverage on it to bargain more 
 
Based on above point 1 to 3 ,it is very negligible plus , minus.  For that I rather drive my car till the day C&C call me for one to one exchange .  
 
As for the loan , 5 years @ 60% .  Take the loan to enjoy the freebie , after 6 months or more, break the loan.  Redeem it, there will be penalty , but all in u still save then fulfill the loan tenure .  Example if I take 3 years loan $80k w C&C at 2.68%.  The interests will be $6k.  If I choose to redeem it after 12 months , all in w penalty it works out to be around $2800.  
 
So with $2800 interests vs all freebie ( GPS, Reverse cam , front + back car cam , floor map and essential pack consists of umbrella , wallet, key chain and backpack) ..... u win 
Again , is my TAKE , my motto as always - To each his OWN

GLC 250 4matic, had this car for slightly more than a year from june 2017.
This car is a crap. To date this junk has 11 issue.
- The car suspension is a crap. It wobbles and sways. Undercarriage has jolts and cranks when turning. 
Really wobbly drive. 
 
- Engine is NOT refined at all as what they claim. It is noisy. Rough engine noise.
Not smooth at all.
 
- Road noise is very apparent. 
- The car does not feel solid at all.
- Strange motor like sound comes out from the engine or dashboard sometimes and is irritating
- Strange ticking sound comes out from the dashboard sometimes.
- Car jerky gear change. 
- Power delivery is not smooth at all. Hesitation.
-Brake squeeling
 
 
Do not belief all the hype about this car. Hard to belief the Germans make this kind of junk car. 
This car did not make the oomph feeling at all for such a price. It does not have even a little bit of luxury feeling. 
Even found a hole after one month of ownership,at the front left passenger foot area. How the hell this got pass the QC check. C&C said it is manufactured in Germany.
 
Went to Merc at Alexandra Rd and dumped the car for them to check on this crap.
Got a temporary replacement car while they check this GLC crap.
 
 
The temp replacement car I got is a 2015 E200.
I tell you this E200 is a Jem. It feels so solid. The drives so, so smooth.
It is a beauty. The engine is so silent compared to the lousy, juncky crappy GLC.
 
Please test drive the E class if you intent to buy the GLC. 
Why did'nt the Germans make the GLC like the E Class? 
 
Though I have this E class temporarily i always look forward to drive it. Driving the E class is a pleasure.
Don't feel like returning the E class to collect back the inferior GLC.
 
Just wish that C&C takes a long time to repair the junk GLC so that I can use the E class longer.
 
The E class built feels really solid and rigid and really feels high quality. Should have test driven the E class before buying the GLC.
 
Belief me the GLC is NOT a good car . Please test drive the E Class and then decide.
 
The E class seems to be the real Mercedes Benz.

Regarding the E200, yes, I driven one for 3 days in Germany. 
Silent, smooth, very comfortable ride. Engaging drive.  All was good on city roads & highways until I brought it to winding roads in the Black Forest.  Suspension was too soft for that kind of roads & handling.  Felt very wobbly on winding roads, had to constantly slowed down drastically.

Regarding the E200, yes, I driven one for 3 days in Germany. 
Silent, smooth, very comfortable ride. Engaging drive.  All was good on city roads & highways until I brought it to winding roads in the Black Forest.  Suspension was too soft for that kind of roads & handling.  Felt very wobbly on winding roads, had to constantly slowed down drastically.
That's why must have AMG line.

There are some stuff you will find out during test drive but not everything. Basically, road noise, acceleration, turning radius and driver seat. The rest like highway speed, top speed, handling and parking, only will know when own the car.

I bought the GLC after testing X3 (last gen) , Xc60, F-pace, Discovery Sports, Q5( last gen). 
 
To be fair, mercedes 2.0 IL4 turbo in 250 tune is one of the better and more refined IL4 turbo I owned (legacy 2.5 boxer turbo, saab 2.0lpt and mini 2.0 turbo) and tested. 
If punches above it's weight even when comparing to the Mercedes 3.5L NA v6 and lexus 3.5 V6 (hybrid no less). 
 
The GLC250 is one of the only 2 cars I owned that sometimes I forgot that the engine is already running and I mistakenly press the start stop button to start it again (resulting in the car turning off). The other is the lexus hybrid. 
 
The 9G tronic matches well with the engine tune such that it is almost stutter free. Only niggle is the 2nd gear can be abit rough relative to the whole range of gear forward motion. 
 
X3 was a good car, very firm ride and handling, but at the end of the life span, PML was very stuck up with the pricing and the base 20i model is anaemic to drive despite the good handling. The 25i was priced at a level which I decided that I still get spare change when I get the GLC250 with panoroof and amg line option... And a brand new platform. 
 
 
 
To be fair, he was just sharing his unfortunate issues with his GLC.But I guess some of his comments touched raw nerves in those who bought it or planning to.There's no need to be mean with name calling.Frankly, I liked the looks of the GLC 250 coupe, went for 2 test drives just to be sure,But didn't like the handling of the car. Steering was numb for me (being a Beemer driver),Engine was noisy, power unrefined & not engaging enough.To each his/her own.Ended up buying a SUV from the building next to it.

Yeah same.
 
I go through all available youtube car reviews of the model to arrive at a decent understanding of the car taking into account not all reviewers put equal weightage on any particular aspect of the car. 
 
Since GLC is a relatively new platform and model with very little local knowledge, I joined overseas Mercedes forums with audience based mainly in USA/UK to get an idea of real life user feedback as well as to have a feel of commonly encountered complaints or problems. So, when I placed my order, tyre crabbing, brake squeel are part of what I have anticipated. All these are done before I even go for a test drive. 
 
When I test drive, I test the accelerator response and gear changes, the drive modes, suspension, steering, turning and ease of parking. Road noise and weird noises are done with the radio off and SE asked to kindly stop taking for a while. 
 
Fit and finish, luggage and passenger space test can be done with the static showroom car. 
 
After I confirmed my purchase, I paid for and installed the factory workshop manual/parts software for mercedes cars. That's how I know how to DIY change my fender trims, front grill and door speakers. 
 
Despite all that, I have to still deal with slowing system clock (pending me sending car in to flash software) and radiator temperature error code which C&C resolved. All these are part and parcel of owning a car. My lexus GS450h also developed hybrid system issue in 4th year while under extended warranty. Does it make it a crap car? No. 
 
Agree fully about all cars will have their pros and cons. Some of the pros might be cons for others. It's about finding the right car with the right combination of pros and cons for your own need.

Decide if you are going for PI ready stock or C&C indent first.
 
Then worry about the pre-FL vs FL.
 
From what I understand about C&C booking system, you pay deposit so that C&C can reserve a build order slot for you from Germany factory. The lead from booking to delivery can take between 6 to 9 mths on average.
 
After placing your booking fee, there is a period whereby you can still make changes to your orders, eg. add options or change colours. Once your car starts production, it is locked in.
 
The lock in period is about 2-3 mths before your estimated delivery.
 
So the question about pre-FL vs FL, you can simply ask the SE which version are you placing your booking for. And when the booking for FL will be open. prices will be different for sure.

Oic..  sounds like though you put 4 identical tyres on the staggered rims, you dont rotate tyres ?

Nope. once you stagger the general rule of thumb is you give up rotation.
 
Rotation is mainly to even out any uneven wear on the tires to prolong their lifespan....how much of the lifespan you prolong is debatable.
 
This is another reason why a lot of people hesitate to go stagger set up for the increased running cost as you might need to change your tyres more frequently.

The reason for considering this staggered tyres on square rims setup?
 
If for looks, the rear staggered (9J vs 8.5J) usually means the 9J rim face is deeper set (ie. deep dish effect) and the rims are usually pushed out abit more (offset play). That is the look that staggered rims achieve when looking from the side and quadrant view. So, using a wider tyre on square rims at the rear will not achieve this effect.
 
of course from the rear, the wider tyre width will look broader and means business.
 
Maybe you can consider using the square rims with square tyres and just add a good quality  H&R Spacer 20-25mm in the rear. That way you pushes out your rear track width, achieve a staggered look and will feel the improvement in lateral stability and cornering road holding.
 
Just a suggestion for you to consider.
